values:
...So I have been deep in thought the last couple of days, thinking about what "home" means. I don't mean the literal definition but the definition we as the human race have philosophically deemed. What makes up a home? I live in an apartment with two of my best friends, "home". We have a pretty functional household and have created a second family commune. There is that understood rule of what's mine is "yours", which of course is only said for a comfortable illusion. All in all, I love living here in Brooklyn with a great base of security and love and a support system. 

I started pondering these questions of "home" after I arrived at work. Before I could take off my jacket, my manager handed me a stack of fliers and told me to go to the front of a subway stop and start handing out fliers to whomever I came across. About an hour into this task, two cops came up and yelled at me to move away from the subway entrance/exit. I guess if I caused someone to have any sort of accident, New York City is held responsible. Good to know.

I ashamedly moved across the street to a different corner of Christopher Street. The air was crisp and cold with a breeze that made the little hairs on the back of my neck and as well on my hand stand. I bounced in place to keep warm. People passed avoiding eye-contact with me and the ones that looked at me looked with disdain. There were the select kind-hearted souls that took my Energy Kitchen fliers, amazed that a white male was passing out fliers. I thought if these few knew that I am a legal resident of the USA (I refrain from using the term "American" because I haven't figured out what that means to me) and that I hold a college degree, they would probably take stacks of fliers at a time or maybe they would put the fliers back in my hand. Who knows, but that brings me to the purpose of this entry. With all my efforts to join the ranks of working middle class, why am I not succeeding? More important, why am I subjecting myself to a job that I am overqualified for and that can't supply me with a uniform that fits? The answer: to pay rent for my "home". So if I love "home" so much, why am I miserable? How can I feel so unsuccessful and without purpose in a place that surrounds me with love and friendship?

I thought my roommates were definitely worth it but not at the expense of sacrificing myself. Maybe home is not where the heart is. Maybe I will not have a "home" until I feel comfortable with who I am in society and among my peers. Then I could achieve a sense of "home" within myself. Maybe I am just in a funk.

...So y'know that feeling you get when your phone rings and you answer and it is "literally" the last person on Earth you wanna talk to? I'm talking about the feeling you have about someone (more annoying than telemarketers), who is such an arduous task or chore if you will to deal with. The person with the "never a good time" quality meaning it's always a bad time because of his presence. Anyway this feeling transcends to your vocal chords and you get this almost melancholy, monotonous tone in your voice and you roll your eyes (almost to the back of your head) to yourself and the only thing you can do is lie to excuse yourself from the phone call. I don't care if you are a compulsive liar or a goody-goody that has never lied or never lies or lies no more, we have all been here lying our asses off to get off the phone. This is the tone of voice I received from my mother when I called to touch base yesterday. There are not many things more painful than this situation, when coming from your own mother. Am debating whether or not I wanna give Ma and Pop the web-link to my journal.

...So I am like -$400 in my bank account, -$500 with the overdraft fees that continue to grow and I have November rent staring me in the face. I can't pay the bank back and I will definitely be short on rent (avoiding my landlords again this month, which causes me pain and embarrassment because they have become my friends). I left a professional job back home in North Dakota where I made $17/hr to move here and chase a dream that I truly have been chasing since High School. Now I live in Brooklyn, work in Manhattan for $7.50 an hour, 12-15 hours per week. I was hired with the promise of full time... ...whatever that means. I understand the sacrifices of chasing one's dream and I know the lifestyle of a starving artist. But at 26 years old, am I insane for continuing this endeavor? 

I am consistently struggling with what I am supposed to take from these experiences. Am I still learning the value of "hanging in there" with the hard work and the financial disappointments? By this (I think) I mean that if I continue pressing forth with my goals and patience (which really isn't patience at times, more of "I don't have a choice" scenario; no money for rent, no money to move), will I get my turn in life's fairytale? Earn everything I have worked for? Will I live happily ever after? Or am I supposed to break my patterns, figure out that my efforts aren't working and move on to something else? Is fate saying I should not be chasing my dreams and I would be figuring it out by the quasi-employment situations, the passive/aggressive behaviors of the professionals in the film industry (from whom I expected better treatment only because I am human) and other blatant "in my face" signs? I think I would shrivel up and die if I found that I am only wasting my talents and time. Our time is valuable! I am seriously positive at this moment. I am not in a negative state of mind so I ask these questions to myself inquisitively. It is such a nice place to be with myself after years of mental self-abuse for the choices I made and the questions I raised. 

It seems such a catch 22 today that if I stay here, I will more than likely suffer depression, loneliness, failure and poverty. And maybe that is who I am; depressed, lonely, poor and unsuccessful. But can and will I turn this around. "This too shall pass" and "nothing lasts forever", right? Don't we learn (like beating a dead horse over and over) that hard work and perseverance pay off? But we also learn that if something isn't working, we go in a different direction. Which is the lesson I am to walk away with? I fear I am running out of tactics. The flip-side would be to go back home to North Dakota, take back my professional job, live within my means, advance in the food chain, be close to my family but have no exposure to what I thought I was here on Earth to do and never completely be who I am. I give up befriending people who I relate to, making films with my creative and talented friends (whom I promised I would bring with me into stardom), dating men that I am attracted to and a lifestyle that I have surrounded myself with. How can I decide betwixt the two situations? So far, I have been making the decision that means the most important to me; living in New York City with an identity. But my money is gone. Yet I survive by taking money out of the ATM as long as they keep providing the cash and I eat my roommates food. I have sang songs to get a pass on the subway and have sold possessions that have had personal value to me. The humility of this man that I have been lately makes me shut everyone out so I don't have to admit my status and my foolish judgments. I have created phobias of talking to my close friends and family, with whom I share everything with. Is the result of my existence here homelessness or isolation? I fear the knowledge that the repercussions of my continued actions will be jail or death. 

I come to the conclusion at times that this person I have become isn't necessarily who I am, and this isn't exactly the identity I wanted. No one should live like this and I have it good compared to others. But at least I am not hiding and ignoring my truths and realities. I guess with everything freedom has a price. But is it stealing when I continue to live here when I can't pay the bills?

Well this is my first journal entry. I am hoping that writing things down will help me tolerate life in the "Big Apple" a little more. Don't get me wrong, life is good. I just know myself to be a little more "ZEN" when I have a written release. I can guarantee myself that I will RANT and TANGENT, writing too much or too little depending on my observations of myself and experiences. 

Well here goes...
